And if you recall,

thermal equilibrium, the
camera potential mu equals 0.

However, I caution you, if you
do in light-emitting devices,

or if you do solar

And that's because in this

let's say, electron holes
that have not the equilibrium, and that's in this

And that's why the light emitted
from a light-emitting diode

or laser can be much higher
than the black body radiation intensity.

And from there, once we
have this average number

of particles, we will discuss
the applications essentially

what we have discussed now
is the quantum mechanics tells me, what's the energy
of any matter I give you?

A crystal, what's the
electron energy levels? What's the phono energy
level, so a molecule or atom?

In principle, we can solve

There's no temperature there. And then, we add it to each

of a quantum state,

this is how many particles we
have at that quantum state. And then, we discuss
the density of states,

that's per near
that energy level, how many of those
quantum states?

So we're doing accounting. And by this time, what
I'm hoping is using--

so we show the black
body radiation, in that case is a [INAUDIBLE]. And the Bose-Einstein
distribution density

of the state of photons. And you can easily say
the black-body radiation are based on this expression.

If you need a chair there,
other chairs are in the front. And then if you take--

so this gives the
energy density, right? And if you take a temperature
derivative of that energy

density, you get
the specific heat. Although for photons we seldom
talk about specific heat,

and that's why for photons
the lattice we can measure, so we use the specific heat.

And the low temperature
you get T-cubic power. And that's very similar to
what is black-body radiation

normal T-force power. That's the energy and the
temperature derivative to give you T-cubic power.

So by the end of
the last lecture, I said I'm going to tell you I
could just stop here and move

to the next chapter. But I'm going to use
half of today's lecture

to tell you the statistical
foundation because there is some very useful language.

I'm not going to
test you, as I said. But I thought it was
really beautiful. So it's good that
you have some-- you

know the terminologies here. So in statistics what
do we want if I have,

for example, a system where
the equilibrium surrounding,

I want to measure
its energy, or I want to measure its temperature. So what I have is
a time average.

I do a certain
amount of measurement over a certain period of
time because instantaneously

those quantities
are fluctuating. So one way to find a
quality that we report

is the time average. But in statistical
mechanics the framework

is developed most along
the ensemble average. There is a time average.

For example, if you do
molecular dynamics simulation, you actually solve
the equation of motion

and you get the
trajectory of the atoms, and you see how to
do the averaging. And the ensemble
average is based on not

considering time history-- so if I have a system, there
are many quantum mechanics

that say, OK, I can go
to solve in principle-- Schrodinger
equation-- I find all

quantum states of the system. So I have quantum state one
and all those quantum states.

And this omega is
typically much, much larger

than the number of
particles you have. In fact, we'll see soon even
one atom, the quantum state--

say the allowable quantum state
in this room for one molecule-- will be much, much larger
than the total number
of molecules in this room. So this is a huge number, omega.

And the ensemble
average is actually looking at each of these quantum
states, the time evolution.

But right now let's
not think about time. Each quantum state,
what's the probability?

So if you do a
statistic averaging, what's the probability for
observing quantum state I?

Right?  And in that quantum state,
what's this quantity Xi?

For example, what's the
energy of that quantum state? What's the momentum
of that quantum state?
Microscopic, right? Where we're targeting. And now the probability--

now for that, say one side of
the system in my ensemble--

this is a many state
form of ensemble, right? So if I know the probability
of observing that quantum

state in the ensemble,
then now the value

that I'm interested in that
specific ensemble, then my average--

the ensemble average--
is then Xi Pi and sum
over all the quantum states.

So this is the concept
of ensemble average. And that's in statistics
we do most of the time.

We don't actually try to
solve the time history, because time
history, like I said,

is only a tool that was
developed so a computer could become very powerful.

You saw, for example, in
molecular dynamics, right?

So there is a very
fundamental assumption

when these two different
ways of averaging are equal to each other.

A system, when the time average
equals the ensemble average,

that's called ergodic.  So ergodic system is
when the time average
equals the ensemble average. And most systems are ergodic.

It turns out that studying
long ergodic systems

is actually an active branch
for strategic physics.

So ergodic system is
one that after some time it tends to equilibrium.
The samples of all the states.

But there are
interesting examples of long ergodic systems. I can't help but
give you one example.

And this example is
a famous problem. The FPU problem.
It's a Fermi-Pasta-Ulam.

So it turns out in the 1950s,
when the computer was just

becoming available,
Fermi-Pasta-Ulam, they

published a report. It was another UN paper. And what they reported
is that they simulated

a one dimensional atomic
chain and the sprint

is not a harmonic. Right? Before when we
started [INAUDIBLE],, we started harmonic.

Kx. F equals Kx. And they added a
higher order term.
A long linear term. And what that long linear term--

this is what they, later
on, would discuss more-- is the cause for scattering.

If I have a perfect
crystal, or that spring, just to say we have
the full picture there,

you have infinite
thermal conductivity because the waves are not
interacting with each other. So if I have a crystal, I
create a disturbance here.

They do not interact. They propagate infinitely. So a perfect crystal with
a perfect harmonic spring

has infinite thermal
conductivity. And most material has a
finite thermal conductivity

because those springs
are long, have a higher order of
terms that start

to interact in different modes. That's a scattering. That's what we're going
to talk about more.

So the reason they started
long harmonic spring is to look at the scattering
in this atomic chain.

But what they found
is very interesting. And they found that if
they put a one mode--

put the energy into one mode-- after some time the energy of
this mode gave to other modes.

But after a long
time of simulating-- so if it's a normal
system, we're

going to approach equilibrium. So every mode gathers
some energy, right?

You put the energy in
one mode, and eventually equal partition and every
mode gets some energy.

But what they found is
that after some time, all the energy came
back to this mode.

OK? So what that implies is that
this system is not ergodic.

It doesn't approach
the equilibrium. And so from that
what they imply--

I'm very interested in
this because they also imply this atomic chain has an
infinite thermal conductivity.

Energy never dissipates. And that was actually

Maybe a polymer chain is

We achieved a 300

That's just a fiber. A single molecule

Maybe even divergent. We have not been

equals time average.

With this I'm going to say
there are different ensembles.

OK? And I'm going to discuss
three major ensembles.

You can construct
your own ensemble. So it depends on the macroscopic
constraint to the total system.

There are three types. One is, I give you a system,
and that's a closed system.

And I fix the total number
of particles, the volume,

and the energy.  So this ensemble has a
fixed amount of energy,

a fixed amount of numbers
of particles, and volume. And that's an isolated system.

Energy is a constant,
and it doesn't interact with the surrounding.
Volume is constant. Number of particles is constant. That's an isolated system.

So it turns out that
the probability-- So what I'm looking
at is, what's

the probability of
observing a quantum state of this macroscopic system
which has many quantum states?

So this is one
type of constraint. And the next type
of constraint, is

I don't do an isolated system. Rather than the
energy as a constant,

I have the temperature
as a constant. So I have N, V, T.
And in this case,

temperature is constant so
the energy can fluctuate, and it can interact with
the surrounding environment.

Let's say the environment is
at a constant temperature. And the third is a
system that I don't need

to fix the number of particles. It can have mass exchange,
particle exchange,

with it's surroundings. So if the particles
are in exchange--

either equilibrium
when my system is-- the thermal equilibrium,
temperature is equal.

When a system has mass
equilibrium, the particle equilibrium, the chemical
potential is equal.

So I deal with the
system the [INAUDIBLE] potential of volume,
temperature is fixed.

The number of particles
are not fixed.  So now for each of these,
I can take a system

and I make an ensemble. And in this case I make an
ensemble of quantum state I.

I for quantum state, that has
a fixed number, N, V, U. What's

And similarly, for this one,
again I is quantum state.

What's the probability? But in this case, I have N,

I do not have fixed energy. And this system may have

specific quantum state--

And the same is for this. In this case, the I quantum

The particle is also not fixed. And I have mu, V, T. So

And the rest of the

And we have specific names for

Here is a microcanonical.
And here is canonical.

Grand canonical. So it's three different

So if I have a total of omega

So equal probability.

of omega quantum state.

So the Boltzmann

of the macroscopic
constraint N, V, U--

so entropy is a function of N,
V, U, which is Kb log omega.
That's the Boltzmann principle.  Boltzmann was very depressed.

He was a great scientist and
didn't get the recognition.

He actually jumped in to a lake. And so if you have a
chance to go to Vienna,

his tombstone is the
S equals Kb log omega.

So what they say
here, is the entropy--

make the entropy
additive quantity. If you have two subsystems,

is the entropy-- the sum of the entropy
of each system. Because if you have two
systems, each one has the omega,

the total combination of the
state is omega 1 times omega 2. So that makes the log
give you the summation.

So the fact that I
have functioning S,

is a functional of N,V, U, this
is called the thermodynamic
function. Thermodynamic potential.

So it turns out for a
microcanonical ensemble,

the thermodynamic
potential is the entropy. If you know entropy as

And using this

This is a du equals a Tds,

Right, this is the form that
